name: Four-wheel carriage
bio: Railway carriages from the 1850s to 1870s tended to be built on wooden or wrought iron frames of around 20-24ft in length, with oil lighting internally.

name: Six-wheel carriage

bio: Early open wagons had simple four-wheeled structures and were typically pulled by horses on quarry lines.

name: Steel open wagon
bio: Steel wagons were introduced in the 1930s to have a longer service life than wooden wagons, which were proving uneconomical for many owners to operate after recessions at the start of the decade.

name: Four-wheel tank wagon
bio: Early four wheel tank wagons are limited to low speeds by their construction and primitive suspension.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}Early four wheel tank wagons are limited to low speeds by their construction and primitive suspension.

name: Cylindrical tank wagon
bio: The GWR's cylindrical tank wagons were built by the Locomotive department, as the iron cylinders used similar techniques to steam engines.

name: Six wheeled tank wagon
bio: Six wheeled tank wagons formed the core of the GWR (and later BR) "milk trains", long freight consists transporting milk from farms to cities.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}Six wheeled tank wagons formed the core of the GWR (and later BR) "milk trains", long freight consists transporting milk from farms to cities.

bio: TTA tankers were constructed on "monobloc" principles and featured automatic braking.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}TTA tankers were constructed on "monobloc" principles and featured automatic braking.

name: TEA tank wagon
bio: Large bogie tankers allowed for carrying heavy loads of liquids at high speeds. The long frames allow tanks to take up more space without fouling axles.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}Large bogie tankers allowed for carrying heavy loads of liquids at high speeds. The long frames allow tanks to take up more space without fouling axles.

name: Livestock van
bio: Livestock traffic was common early on in railway history, with specialised cattle wagons and stations equipped to handle loading and unloading.

bio: Simple canvas-covered wagons were some of the earliest vehicles for moving piece goods which needed to be sheltered from the elements.

name: Wooden-framed van
bio: Piece goods were an important source of revenue for early railways, with most building large quantities of covered vans.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}Piece goods were an important source of revenue for early railways, with most building large quantities of covered vans.

name: Iron-framed van
bio: This goods van uses an iron frame with a wooden body, making it stronger than earlier wooden-framed vans.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}This goods van uses an iron frame with a wooden body, making it stronger than earlier wooden-framed vans.

name: Fitted van
bio: Fitted vans had brakes which could be controlled from the locomotive or a brake van, allowing higher braking force and thus speed. This example is typical of a Southern Railways vacuum-braked model.

name: VWV "Vanwide" van
bio: The Vanwide was BR's final development of the traditional van design, featuring wider doors for increased loading speed.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}The Vanwide was BR's final development of the traditional van design, featuring wider doors for increased loading speed.

name: VDA van
bio: The VDA was BR's first air braked general purpose van, later used for the Speedlink freight network.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.5 tiles{}{SILVER}The VDA was BR's first air braked general purpose van, later used for the Speedlink freight network.

name: VEA van
bio: VEA vans were refurbished vans fitted with improved suspension and air brakes, allowing higher speed operation while still being suitable for narrow radius curves in small yards.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}VEA vans were refurbished vans fitted with improved suspension and air brakes, allowing higher speed operation while still being suitable for narrow radius curves in small yards.

name: VGA van
bio: VGA vans followed continental practice with doors extending into the roof panel, providing a larger vertical opening.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.5 tiles{}{SILVER}VGA vans followed continental practice with doors extending into the roof panel, providing a larger vertical opening.

name: GWR "Siphon G" van
bio: GWR's "Siphon" vans were built to carry loads of milk churns at passenger train speeds. They were also used for parcel and newspaper traffic, the basic design being built well into the BR era.

name: Parcels van
bio: BR built several of these six-wheeled parcels vans in the early 1950s.

name: 1 Horse
bio: Most early industrial railways used two sources of power: horses and gravity. Often horses would ride downhill in dandy wagons, to save their energy for pulling the train uphill.

bio: The power of a horse-drawn train can easily be doubled by the expedient addition of a second horse.

name: "Puffing Billy"
bio: Puffing Billy was the first steam locomotive to operate by the adhesion of the wheels alone, all previous locomotives using a rack by the railside. The real version was very slow, capable only of walking speeds.

bio: Originally named "Active", the Stockton and Darlington's Locomotion No. 1 was the first steam locomotive to operate on a public railway. Unfortunately the early design was flawed and it soon became obsolete.

bio: Timothy Hackworth was an influential early locomotive engineer. The Royal George locomotive was built around the boiler from an earlier locomotive Chittaprat, and was capable of hauling heavy coal trains.

bio: Brandreth's "Cycloped" was the only entry in the Rainhill Trials not powered by steam. Unfortunately during the trials the horse burst through the floor, withdrawing it from the competition.

bio: Although not the first steam locomotive, Rocket's advanced design and success in the Rainhill trials made it the pivotal design for steam engines to replace horses on the railway.
